breathing.intro: This chapter could save a life. Be present.
breathing.instructions: Every word here matters. Every detail serves clarity.

story.content:
Marcus had been a volunteer for three events. He knew the protocols. He'd never had to use them.

Day 4 of his fourth event, during the afternoon meditation, he noticed a man three rows backâ€”late 50s, heavysetâ€”whose face had gone gray. Sweating. Clutching his chest.

Marcus's heart rate spiked. *This is it. This is the real thing.*

He pulled out his phone. Opened Telegram. His hands were shaking.

He started typing: "Someone doesn't look good inâ€”"

Then he stopped. Deleted it.

*No. Do it right. Do it exactly like the training.*

He took a breath. Centered himself. Typed the proper format:

ðŸš¨ðŸš¨ MEDICAL EMERGENCY ðŸš¨ðŸš¨
Name: Unknown (conscious, can't speak)
EMERGENCY: Chest pain, gray face, heavy sweating, clutching chest
Team: Blue
Phone: Will get when he can speak
Location: Blue section, center aisle, row 8, seat 12
Room: Unknown
I am staying with the participant

Sent.

He moved to the man. Knelt beside him. Made eye contact. "Help is coming. Medical team is on the way. I'm staying right here with you."

The man nodded. Couldn't speak. Terrified.

Marcus stayed. Kept his voice calm. Kept his presence steady. Even though inside, he was terrified too.

Ninety seconds later, Medical arrived. They had equipment. They knew exactly what to do. They took over seamlessly.

Marcus stepped back. Let them work. Stayed nearby in case they needed him.

The man was okay. Panic attack, not heart attack. But Medical treated it seriously. Monitored him. Got him stabilized. Followed protocol.

After the session, the Medical Lead found Marcus: "That was textbook. Perfect format. Perfect response. You did everything right."

Marcus realized something that day:

The format isn't bureaucracy. It's clarity under pressure. When your hands are shaking and someone's life might be in danger, you don't have to think about what to say. You just follow the format. It holds you steady.

The protocol isn't cold. It's compassionate. It ensures the person gets the right help fast.

And staying with them? That's not just procedure. That's presence. That's the human piece that makes the protocol sacred.

This chapter teaches you that format. That protocol. That presence.

Not so you can be perfect. So you can be effective when someone's life might depend on it.

whyThisMatters.quote: Clarity is the pathway to freedom.
whyThisMatters.author: Dr. Joe Dispenza
whyThisMatters.content:
When someone needs medical help, every second counts. But so does clarity.

A vague messageâ€”'Someone's sick in the ballroom'â€”wastes time. Medical doesn't know who, where, or what's wrong. They arrive unprepared.

A clear messageâ€”exact location, specific symptoms, participant identificationâ€”gets the right response immediately. They bring the right equipment. They find the person fast. They can act.

This is why Encephalon has a specific protocol. Not to create hoops to jump throughâ€”to save lives efficiently.

**All medical requests go through ONE channel:** The official Telegram Team Chat, in the Medical/Mental subtopic section.

Why Telegram? Why not just yell for help?

Because Telegram creates:

â€¢ **Visibility:** The entire medical team sees the request simultaneously
â€¢ **Documentation:** There's a record of what was reported and when
â€¢ **Coordination:** Multiple team members can respond or update
â€¢ **Clarity:** Written details are clearer than shouted instructions
â€¢ **Backup:** If the primary responder is busy, others can take it

This system works. But only if you use it correctly.

**Why this chapter matters:**

**1. You're the early warning system**

Medical can't be everywhere. But you're positioned with participants throughout the event. You see the baseline. You notice when someone's color changes, when their breathing shifts, when they're in distress.

You're the eyes and ears that activate the medical response. Without you, critical situations might go unnoticed until they're worse.

**2. Format creates clarity in crisis**

When someone's in distress and you're scared, your brain doesn't work normally. You forget things. You get flustered. You leave out critical details.

The 7-element format gives you a structure to follow when you can't think clearly. Name. Symptoms. Location. Phone. Room. Photo. It's a checklist that ensures nothing important gets missed.

**3. Speed matters, but so does accuracy**

Getting help fast is critical. But getting the RIGHT help fast is even more critical.

If you report symptoms clearly, Medical knows what equipment to bring. If you give exact location, they don't waste time searching. If you include phone number, they can follow up even if the person moves.

Every detail serves speed and effectiveness.

**4. You're protecting everyone's experience**

When medical situations are handled smoothlyâ€”quickly, quietly, competentlyâ€”most participants don't even notice. The field stays coherent. The meditation continues. The container holds.

When they're handled poorlyâ€”confusion, delays, visible chaosâ€”it affects everyone. Participants get anxious. The energy shifts. The container weakens.

Your clear communication protects the collective experience.

**5. This is life-or-death competence**

This isn't theoretical. At every event, there are medical situations. Falls. Seizures. Cardiac events. Diabetic emergencies. Severe reactions.

The volunteer who knows the protocol and executes it calmly can be the difference between a manageable situation and a tragedy.

That's not hyperbole. That's reality.

**This chapter teaches you:**

â€¢ The exact Telegram format for medical requests
â€¢ The 7 essential elements every request must include
â€¢ How to assess severity (emergency vs. urgent vs. standard)
â€¢ What to do if there's no response
â€¢ How to stay present with someone in distress
â€¢ The deeper practice of clarity under pressure

This is sacred work. Not because it's dramatic. Because when someone's in pain or danger, your clarity and competence create safety.

Learn this. Practice this. Until it's automatic.

learningObjectives: Master the exact Telegram format for requesting medical assistance
Know the 7 critical pieces of information every request must include
Understand when to escalate if there's no response
Practice writing clear, actionable medical requests under pressure

sections.title: The Sacred Channel: Telegram Team Chat
sections.content:
**Critical rule:** ALL medical requests go through the official Telegram Team Chat in the Medical/Mental subtopic section.

Not through:. Private messages to the medic. Direct messages to your Team Lead. Shouting across the ballroom. Text messages to anyone's personal phone. Any other channel

**Why this matters:**

When you post in the Team Chat Medical/Mental subtopic, EVERYONE on the medical team sees it. If the primary medic is with another participant, someone else responds. If they're all busy, Team Leads can see and escalate.

Private messages create blind spots. Only one person sees. If they're busy, no one else knows someone needs help.

Team Chat = visibility = backup = faster response.

**How to find it:**

1. Open Telegram
2. Navigate to [Event Name] Team Chat
3. Look for Topics (threaded conversations)
4. Find 'Medical/Mental' subtopic
5. Post there

If you can't find the subtopic, post in the main Team Chat with ðŸš¨ MEDICAL at the start. Someone will redirect you, but the request will be seen.

**Never:** Send medical requests anywhere else. This is non-negotiable.

pullQuote.text: Preparation is the key to spontaneous action.
pullQuote.author: Dr. Joe Dispenza

sections.title: The 7 Essential Elements: What Every Request Must Include
sections.content:
Every medical request must contain these 7 elements. Memorize this format:

**1. Alert Header**

ðŸš¨ MEDICAL ASSISTANCE NEEDED
(Or ðŸš¨ MEDICAL EMERGENCY if life-threatening)

**2. Name of Participant**. First and last name if possible. If unknown: 'Name unknown' but describe them

**3. Issue/Symptoms (Be Specific)**. What you're seeing: 'clutching chest,' 'fell and hit head,' 'vomiting'. Not: 'doesn't look good' or 'something's wrong'. Objective observations, not interpretations

**4. Team Color/Name**. Red, Blue, Green, Purple, Orange, or Yellow. Helps medical locate them quickly

**5. Phone Number**. Participant's mobile number. Critical for follow-up if they're moved

**6. Current Location**. Specific: 'Blue section, left side, row 12, seat 5'. Not: 'somewhere in the ballroom'. Include landmarks if relevant: 'near the stage,' 'by exit door 3'

**7. Room Number/Hotel**. Where they're staying. Needed if they need to rest or medical follow-up later

**BONUS: Photo**. If appropriate and respectful. Shows face and name badge clearly. Helps medical identify them quickly in a crowded room. Never take photos of injuries or undressed participants

**Why all 7 matter:**

Missing any one element slows response. Name + location = fast identification. Symptoms = right equipment. Phone = ability to follow up. Hotel room = continuity of care.

Don't make medical hunt for information. Give them everything they need to act immediately.

sections.title: The Exact Format: Your Template
sections.content:
Here's the format. Copy it. Save it. Use it.

**STANDARD REQUEST:**

ðŸš¨ MEDICAL ASSISTANCE NEEDED
. Name: [First Last]. Issue/Symptoms: [Specific observable symptoms]. Team: [Color]. Phone: [###-###-####]. Location: [Precise location in venue]. Room: [Room # at Hotel Name]. Photo: [Attach if appropriate]

**EMERGENCY REQUEST:**

ðŸš¨ðŸš¨ MEDICAL EMERGENCY ðŸš¨ðŸš¨
. Name: [First Last]. EMERGENCY: [Chest pain/Unconscious/Seizure/Severe bleeding/etc.]. Team: [Color]. Phone: [###-###-####]. Location: [EXACT location]. Room: [Room # at Hotel Name]. I am staying with the participant

**Examples:**

**Example 1: Non-Emergency**

ðŸš¨ MEDICAL ASSISTANCE NEEDED
. Name: Sarah Mitchell. Issue: Reports feeling nauseous and dizzy, face is pale. Team: Green. Phone: 310-555-7723. Location: Green section, right side, row 5, seat 8. Room: 215, Marriott. Photo: Attached

**Example 2: Emergency**

ðŸš¨ðŸš¨ MEDICAL EMERGENCY ðŸš¨ðŸš¨
. Name: Robert Chang. EMERGENCY: Fell during walking meditation, hit head on floor, small amount of bleeding, conscious but disoriented. Team: Purple. Phone: 206-555-4391. Location: Main ballroom floor, left side near stage. Room: 518, Hilton. I am staying with the participant

Notice:. Symptoms are specific and observable. Location is precise enough to navigate. Contact info is complete. Emergency status is crystal clear

This is the standard. This is what saves time. This is what saves lives.

sections.title: The Decision Tree: What Issue Requires What Action
sections.content:
Use this guide to determine how to act based on what you're seeing.

**IMMEDIATE MEDICAL EMERGENCY** (Call + Stay + Get help in person if possible):. Chest pain or severe difficulty breathing â†’ Stay with participant, post in Telegram, notify nearest staff. Unconscious or signs of seizure â†’ Same protocol. Active severe bleeding â†’ Same protocol. Signs of stroke (face droop, arm weakness, speech difficulty) â†’ Same protocol. Any life-threatening condition â†’ Same protocol

**URGENT MEDICAL** (Post in Telegram + Stay):. Hard fall ANY TIME during event â†’ Stay with participant, post request. Actively bleeding (not severe) â†’ Same. In significant pain â†’ Same. Reports feeling very ill â†’ Same

**STANDARD MEDICAL** (Post in Telegram + Escort or Direct):. Reports feeling ill (mild) â†’ Post request, then escort to Medical Table or direct them to go. Nauseous or vomits â†’ Post request, get vomit bag from Medical/Customer Service, stay with them. Requests temperature or blood pressure check â†’ Post request, escort to Medical Table. Medication questions â†’ Post request, direct to Medical Table

**Key principles:**. Life-threatening = Stay with them + Post + Get in-person help. Urgent = Stay with them + Post. Standard = Post + Escort or direct to Medical Table. Never send someone to their hotel room without medical evaluation first. Never lose track of someone who fellâ€”stay with them until medical arrives

**Special note for Cancun events:**

There's an on-site ambulatory clinic. But NEVER send participants there without first being assessed by event medical team. Always follow standard protocolâ€”Medical evaluates, then decides if clinic is needed.

sections.title: When There's No Response: The Escalation Protocol
sections.content:
You've posted in Telegram. You're waiting. No one's responding.

Here's what to do:

**If 10 minutes pass with no response:**

**Step 1: Check the chat**. Did your message post correctly?. Are you in the right subtopic?. Is your phone working?

**Step 2: Escalate in person**. Find the nearest Customer Service team member. OR find a Green Hat (Team Lead). Show them your Telegram post. They will escalate urgently

**Step 3: If it's an emergency and you can't wait 10 minutes:**. Don't wait for Telegram response. Immediately find any Green Hat or Customer Service. Have them radio for medical while you stay with the participant. Post in Telegram anyway for documentation

**Why 10 minutes is the threshold:**

Medical team is usually very responsive. If 10 minutes pass, either:. They're all with other participants (rare but possible). There's a technical issue with Telegram. Your message didn't go to the right place

Escalating to Customer Service/Team Leads ensures someone with direct radio contact to medical can get help.

**What NOT to do:**. Don't assume they saw it and decided it's not important. Don't leave the participant to go find help yourself if they're in distress. Don't post multiple messages (clogs the channel)â€”escalate in person instead. Don't give up and handle it yourself

The system works. But humans make mistakes. Networks fail. If the protocol isn't working, escalate. Always.

sections.title: After You Call: What Happens Next
sections.content:
You've sent the request. Medical is on their way. Now what?

**While you wait (usually 1-5 minutes):**. Stay with the participant. Keep them calm with your presence. Don't diagnose or speculate about what's wrong. Don't give medical advice. Just be present, grounded, reassuring

**When Medical arrives:**. Briefly tell them what you observed. Give them space to work. Stay nearby in case they need you. Don't crowd them or watch intensely. If they dismiss you, return to your post

**If they need more info:**. Answer their questions factually. 'She said her chest hurt' not 'I think she's having a heart attack'. Stick to what you observed, not what you interpret

**If they move the participant:**. Note where they're going (Medical table, quiet room, outside for fresh air). Update your Team Lead if it affects your section coverage. Don't follow unless Medical asks you to

**After the situation is resolved:**. Return to your post. Don't gossip about what happened. Don't share details with other volunteers or participants. If you're shaken, talk to your Team Lead privately

**Documentation:**

Your Telegram message IS the documentation. Medical team uses it for their records. Don't delete it. Don't edit it to 'clean it up' after the fact.

If you made an error in your message (wrong name, wrong room number), post a brief correction:
'Correction: Room 412, not 421'

That's it. Simple. Clear. Effective.

reflection.title: Clarity Under Pressure
reflection.content:
You're learning to stay clear when everything is chaos.

When someone's body is in crisis. When you don't know what's wrong. When every second matters.

This is profound training.

Not just in protocols. In presence. In the capacity to notice your own fear rising and still act from clarity.

When you see someone whose face has gone gray, whose breathing is labored, whose body is strugglingâ€”your nervous system activates. That's natural. That's your body recognizing danger.

But you're learning something more sophisticated: to notice that activation and still respond clearly.

To pull out your phone. To open Telegram. To write the seven elements even though your hands are shaking. To stay with them until help arrives.

This is what it means to serve under pressure.

You're not learning to be fearless. You're learning to act despite fear. To trust the protocol when your mind is spinning. To stay present when everything in you wants to panic or freeze.

And here's what develops in you through this practice:

The capacity to be reliable when it matters most. To be the person others can count on in crisis. To be steady when others can't be.

This serves you everywhere. Not just at events. In your life. Every moment when someone needs you to stay clear and act.

You're also learning the profound importance of precision.

The seven elements aren't bureaucracy. They're clarity. They ensure Medical has what they need to help. They create continuity of care. They protect the person in crisis.

When you write "Participant name: John Smith" instead of "someone"â€”you're seeing them as a person, not a problem.

When you write "Issue: chest pain, gray face, difficulty breathing" instead of "doesn't look good"â€”you're giving Medical information they can act on.

When you write "I am with them"â€”you're making a commitment. You're saying: they're not alone. I'm here. I'm staying.

That precision is love in action.

You're learning that your regulated state matters. That when you stay coherent, you create safety. That your calm becomes their calm.

Dr. Joe teaches this: your state affects the field. When you're grounded, others can orient to that groundedness.

This is why you practice. Why you learn the format. Why you rehearse staying present under pressure.

So that when the moment comesâ€”and it will comeâ€”you're ready. Not perfect. Ready.

You'll make mistakes. You'll forget elements. You'll second-guess yourself. That's part of learning.

But each time you call Medical, each time you stay present with someone in crisis, each time you act from clarity instead of panicâ€”you're strengthening your capacity to serve.

And here's what you're really learning:

That you can handle intensity. That you can be trusted in crisis. That your presence matters when someone's body is struggling.

You're becoming someone who doesn't look away. Who doesn't freeze. Who acts.

Not heroically. Just clearly. Just present. Just human.

That's the practice. That's who you're becoming. That's what it means to hold space when bodies need care.

reflection.prompt: Imagine you're monitoring your section and someone needs medical help. How does it feel to know exactly what to do? What would help you stay calm enough to follow the protocol clearly?

quiz.question: You see a participant suddenly clutch her chest and double over in pain. Her lips are turning blue. What do you do FIRST?

options.text: Stay with her while immediately opening Telegram to post a medical emergency request with all required details
options.feedback: Yes. Chest pain with blue lips is a medical emergency. You stay with her (so she's not alone and you can monitor changes) while simultaneously posting the urgent request. If possible, also signal a nearby Team Lead or staff member for immediate in-person backup. You're doing both: staying present AND getting help fast.

options.text: Run to find the nearest medic or Team Lead to tell them in person
options.feedback: If you run to find help, you leave her aloneâ€”and in an emergency, that's dangerous. She could lose consciousness, fall, worsen. Your Telegram post reaches ALL medical staff instantly. Stay with her, post the emergency, signal anyone nearby if possibleâ€”but don't abandon her to find help.

options.text: Call 911 immediately since this looks like a heart attack
options.feedback: The medical team determines if 911 is needed. They're licensed healthcare professionals who can assess. Your job: alert them immediately via Telegram with ðŸš¨ðŸš¨ MEDICAL EMERGENCY. They'll decide if emergency services are needed and will call if so. Don't bypass the systemâ€”use it so professionals can assess.

options.text: Ask her if she wants medical help before calling anyone
options.feedback: In a medical emergency, you don't wait for permission. Blue lips indicate oxygen deprivationâ€”she may not be thinking clearly. Call for medical immediately. If she refuses treatment when they arrive, that's her choice to make with medical professionalsâ€”but get them there first. Time matters with cardiac symptoms.

quiz.question: Write the correct Telegram message for this scenario: During lunch break, Michael Torres (Team Yellow, phone 303-555-8821, staying in Room 734 at the Marriott) approaches you saying he threw up in the bathroom and feels dizzy. He looks pale and is sweating.

options.text:
ðŸš¨ MEDICAL ASSISTANCE NEEDED

â€¢ Name: Michael Torres
â€¢ Issue: Vomiting and dizziness, appears pale and sweating
â€¢ Team: Yellow
â€¢ Phone: 303-555-8821
â€¢ Location: Near bathrooms, main ballroom level
â€¢ Room: 734, Marriott
options.feedback: Perfect. You've included all 7 elements: alert header, name, specific symptoms (vomiting, dizziness, pale, sweating), team, phone, location, and room. The symptoms are observable and specific. Location makes sense (he's with you near bathrooms). This gets medical there with full information.

options.text: Michael Torres is sick and needs help. He's with me near the bathrooms. Yellow team.
options.feedback: This is too vague and missing critical info. No alert emoji, no phone number, no room number, no specific symptoms. 'Sick' could mean anything. Medical doesn't know if they need to bring anti-nausea meds, IV equipment, or what. Use the full formatâ€”it exists for a reason.

options.text:
ðŸš¨ MEDICAL EMERGENCY

â€¢ Name: Michael Torres
â€¢ Issue: Vomiting, possible food poisoning
â€¢ Team: Yellow
â€¢ Phone: 303-555-8821  
â€¢ Location: Bathrooms
â€¢ Room: 734, Marriott
options.feedback: Close, but two issues: (1) This isn't a life-threatening emergency, so ðŸš¨ MEDICAL ASSISTANCE NEEDED is more appropriate than MEDICAL EMERGENCY. (2) Don't diagnose ('possible food poisoning')â€”just describe symptoms. Say 'vomiting and dizziness, appears pale and sweating.' Let medical determine the cause.

options.text:
ðŸš¨ MEDICAL ASSISTANCE NEEDED

Michael Torres, Yellow team, just vomited and feels dizzy. He's pale. I'm with him near the bathrooms. His phone is 303-555-8821. He's in room 734 at Marriott.
options.feedback: This works. While not in the exact bullet-point format, it contains all the necessary information clearly. In an urgent moment, this level of clarity is acceptableâ€”you've given medical everything they need. The bullet format is cleaner and easier to scan quickly, but this accomplishes the same goal.

quiz.question: You post a medical request at 2:47 PM. It's now 2:54 PM and no one has responded or arrived. The participant is still in pain. What do you do?

options.text: Continue waitingâ€”it's only been 7 minutes, and the 10-minute threshold hasn't been reached yet
options.feedback: Correct. The protocol says 10 minutes. Medical may be finishing with another participant, gathering equipment, or en route. Seven minutes feels long when you're with someone in pain, but it's within normal response time. Stay present with the participant. Comfort them. If it becomes an emergency (worsening symptoms, loss of consciousness), then escalate immediately regardless of time.

options.text: Post another message in Telegram asking if anyone saw the first request
options.feedback: Don't clutter the channel. They saw it. If they haven't responded by 10 minutes, escalate in personâ€”don't post again. Multiple messages make it harder for everyone to track what's happening. Trust the system until the 10-minute mark, then escalate to Customer Service or a Green Hat.

options.text: Find the nearest Green Hat or Customer Service member and show them your Telegram post to escalate
options.feedback: Also acceptable, especially if the participant is in significant distress. While 10 minutes is the official threshold, using your judgment to escalate slightly early (at 7-8 minutes) if symptoms are severe is appropriate. You're not panickingâ€”you're being proactive. Show them your post so they know you followed protocol first.

options.text: Leave your post to go to the Medical Table and tell them directly
options.feedback: Don't leave the participant or your post. If you need to escalate, signal a nearby volunteer to go while you stay. Or use the Green Hat/Customer Service escalation method. The participant needs your presence, and your post needs your attention. Don't abandon either to deliver a message that should have already been seen.

quiz.question: A participant fell and hit her head during walking meditation. There's a small cut bleeding, but she's conscious and talking. Write the appropriate Telegram message. Her name is Jennifer Walsh, Team Blue, phone 415-555-3921, Room 203 at the Hilton. She's on the main ballroom floor near the stage.

options.text:
ðŸš¨ MEDICAL ASSISTANCE NEEDED

â€¢ Name: Jennifer Walsh
â€¢ Issue: Fell during walking meditation, hit head, small cut with bleeding, conscious and alert
â€¢ Team: Blue
â€¢ Phone: 415-555-3921
â€¢ Location: Main ballroom floor, near stage
â€¢ Room: 203, Hilton
â€¢ I am staying with the participant
options.feedback: Excellent. You've noted it's a head injury from a fall (medical will bring appropriate equipment), specified she's conscious (critical information), described the bleeding as 'small cut' (helps them gauge urgency), and noted you're staying with her (so medical knows someone's monitoring). This is textbook perfect.

options.text:
ðŸš¨ðŸš¨ MEDICAL EMERGENCY ðŸš¨ðŸš¨

â€¢ Name: Jennifer Walsh  
â€¢ EMERGENCY: Head injury with bleeding
â€¢ Team: Blue
â€¢ Phone: 415-555-3921
â€¢ Location: Ballroom floor near stage
â€¢ Room: 203, Hilton
options.feedback: This overcalls it as an emergency. She's conscious, alert, and it's described as a small cut. This is urgent medical assistance, yesâ€”but not a medical emergency in the life-threatening sense. Use ðŸš¨ MEDICAL ASSISTANCE NEEDED. Save the double-emoji emergency for unconscious, severe bleeding, cardiac, etc. Accuracy in triage helps medical prioritize correctly.

options.text: Jennifer Walsh fell and has a cut on her head. Blue team, on the floor near stage. Room 203 Hilton. Phone 415-555-3921. Someone come quick.
options.feedback: Missing the alert emoji, and 'someone come quick' adds emotional urgency without clarity. Also doesn't note that you're staying with her or that she's consciousâ€”both important details. Use the full format with all elements. 'Come quick' is understoodâ€”specific information is what they actually need.

options.text:
ðŸš¨ MEDICAL ASSISTANCE NEEDED

â€¢ Name: Jennifer Walsh
â€¢ Issue: Fall with possible concussion, minor bleeding
â€¢ Team: Blue  
â€¢ Phone: 415-555-3921
â€¢ Location: Ballroom floor, stage area
â€¢ Room: 203, Hilton
â€¢ Staying with participant
options.feedback: Close, but don't diagnose ('possible concussion'). You don't know if it's a concussionâ€”that's for medical to determine. Just describe what you see: 'fell, hit head, small cut with bleeding, conscious and alert.' Objective observation, not medical interpretation. Let the professionals diagnose.

keyPoints: ALL medical requests go through Telegram Team Chat, Medical/Mental subtopicâ€”nowhere else
Every request must include 7 elements: alert, name, symptoms, team, phone, location, room
Be specific and objective with symptomsâ€”what you see, not what you think it means
Life-threatening emergencies: Stay with participant + Post + Get in-person help
If no response in 10 minutes, escalate to Customer Service or Green Hat
Never send someone to their hotel room without medical evaluation first
Your Telegram message is documentationâ€”don't delete or heavily edit after posting
summary.integration:
You now know the exact protocol. The precise format. The specific actions.

This isn't about memorizationâ€”it's about muscle memory. Practice writing these messages. Imagine scenarios. Rehearse in your mind.

So that when it mattersâ€”when someone is in pain, when seconds count, when pressure is highâ€”you don't have to think.

You just act. Clearly. Quickly. Correctly.

This is preparation. This is what makes sacred service possible.

You're ready.
